unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Volunteering: Mean and Standard Deviation of a Distribution
question_text:
According to U. S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, between September 2014 and September 2015, about $25\%$ of the population (age $16$ and older) volunteered with or through an organization at least once. Suppose this value has not changed.
In random samples of adults of size $n=50$, what is the mean and standard deviation of the number of individuals who would say they have volunteered with or through an organization at least once?
solution:
This situation meets the criteria for the binomial setting because:

There are a fixed number of observations in each sample ($n=50$).

There are only two possible outcomes on each observation. Those sampled either will OR will not have volunteered at least once.

The probability of success (someone saying that they have volunteered at least once) is the same on each observation
(p=0.25).

For binomial distributions, the mean can be calculated using the following formula:

μ=np

...where n is the sample size and p is the probability of success.

Filling in this formula we have:

μ=(50)(0.25)=12.5

For binomial distributions, the standard deviation can be calculated using the following formula:

√
(n)(p)(1−p)

Filling in this formula we have:

√
(50)(0.25)(0.75)
=3.0619

Both of the above formulas can be found in the reference materials provided with the AP Exam. Make sure you know ahead of time what materials will be provided to you.
